parts.title: Resilience in Crisis
parts.body: During WWII, London was expected to crumble under German bombings, yet the British people demonstrated unexpected resilience and calm. Despite severe damage and casualties, there wasn't widespread panic; in fact, mental health improved, with fewer cases of suicide and alcoholism. The city's unity and determination baffled even the Nazis. This chapter posits against veneer theory, suggesting that in crisis, humans often showcase their best selves, challenging a long-standing belief in our inherent savagery.

parts.title: Shaping Reality: Beliefs, Media, and Human Nature
parts.body:
Humanity's Grim View and the Media Effect

The 'nocebo effect' suggests that negative beliefs can shape reality, just as our grim view of humanity influences social behavior and global challenges like climate crisis. Ideas have power, and thinking most people aren't trustworthy leads to distrust and cynicism, deteriorating society. Our view on human nature needs re-evaluation to instigate change. The news perpetuates a culture of negativity, skewing perception with exceptional and shocking stories that make people believe the world is deteriorating, despite evidence of global improvement.

Cynicism in Culture and Science

Throughout history, from ancient Greeks to modern thinkers, the idea persists that humans are inherently selfish and flawed. Thinkers like Nietzsche and Freud labelled humans as murderers or cowards, cementing the idea of the 'veneer theory,' where civilization barely conceals our true nature. This view, seen as realistic by many, is now challenged by recent scientific findings that call for a more hopeful reevaluation. Real change requires standing up for human goodness, battling the cynicism that pervades the culture.

parts.title: Boys' Arrest, Movie Rights & New Beginnings
parts.body: When the six boys returned to Nukuʻalofa, they were immediately arrested for stealing a boat. But thanks to Peter Warner, who cleverly secured movie rights for their story, the boys were released. The aim was to produce a documentary starring the boys. Although the film crew faced difficulties, especially when swimming to the island, the documentary flopped. However, the boys' triumphant return home made them local heroes, celebrated by the entire island. Peter, considered a hero, asked King Taufa‘ahau Tupou IV permission to start a business, uniting the boys once more as the crew on his new boat, which he named "Ata."

parts.title: Contemplating Neanderthals - Weakness or Brain Size?
parts.body: Researchers realized that 50,000 years ago, there were at least five other hominins besides humans: Homo erectus, Homo floresiensis, and more. These were humans, just like different types of finches are all birds. People wonder what happened to the Neanderthals. Some questions arise: Were Neanderthals weaker? No, they were strong like rodeo cowboys. Tests show Neanderthals' bone fractures were similar to injuries seen in rodeos. Maybe Neanderthals were not as smart? Evidence suggests their brains were larger than ours. They cooked, created tools, and possibly even influenced our burial practices.

parts.title: The Reluctance to Kill: Marshall's Discoveries & Controversy
parts.body: During the after World War II years, Samuel Marshall gained a stellar reputation for his revolutionary discoveries about combat behavior—that many soldiers didn't actually shoot their weapons. In his book 'Men Against Fire,' Marshall argued that there is a natural resistance to killing, marking a challenging concept during a period dominated by Hobbesian theories of innate aggression. While his findings were controversial, with accusations of inaccuracies and faked reports, subsequent research revealed similar observations by others, reinforcing the validity of Marshall's theory. Studies showed that even across different conflicts and eras, a small percentage of soldiers were actually engaging in fire, suggesting an innate reluctance towards violence.

parts.title: Revisiting Human Civilization and Easter Island's Lessons
parts.body: Civilization's development saw the transformation from nomadic tribes to settled communities, bringing tangible advances like writing, money, and legal systems, but also reinforcing oppression. Slavery and inequality thrived, and despite surviving into the industrial era, great thinkers justified this exploitation as necessary for progress. Historic empires like the Chinese and others used engineering feats such as the Great Wall not just for defense, but as tools of oppression. Human history was littered with warfare and disease. Scientific revolution and recent technological advances finally began lifting humanity out of perpetual misery around the 18th century, showing a stark contrast compared to the preceding dark periods. The dark ages post-civilization collapses were more reprieves than setbacks, often allowing freedom and healthier societies to flourish temporarily. Scholarship has started reevaluating narratives, understanding 'barbarianism' often signified sustainable living. The opening of the chapter discusses why nomadic life flourished, highlighting Easter Island where European explorers historically painted an image of a civilization in decline. Conventional theories posited deforestation by Easter Islanders themselves led to ecological collapse. However, new investigations suggest an alternative narrative: Rats might have been responsible for deforestation. Dutch and other explorers witnessed a thriving society before their arrival disrupted it, raising suspicions intra-tribal warfare didn't occur as documented. Research indicates Easter Island was more of a societal mystery than a historical cautionary tale, shedding light on how anthropological views can be skewed. The arrival of Roggeveen introduces a bittersweet saga of initial peaceful encounters later tainted by violence as Europeans misinterpreted and interjected their norms, misconstruing Easter Island's actual historical narrative. Scholars emphasize skepticism against Hobbesian views, recognizing Rousseau's defensive, freeing perspective on primitive living conditions.

parts.title: Easter Island Collapse: A Misunderstood History
parts.body: Easter Island's collapse was not self-inflicted but caused by foreign intervention. Contrary to myths, deforestation made the land more productive, there was no mass slaughter in 1680, and foreign visitors hastened their decline. Easter Islanders were resilient, adapting to new farming techniques after their forests were gone. Post-1860, Peruvian slavers took many citizens, spreading disease upon their return, decimating the population to 110 by 1877. Easter Islanders’ story is one of survival, not doom, showcasing adaptability against severe odds. They serve as a hopeful metaphor for resilience in the face of climate change challenges.

parts.title: Experiment with Simplicity
parts.body: Six prisoners escaped and headed to the guards' canteen, ending up enjoying a smoke together. They eventually voted to create a commune, and despite the guards’ belated effort to return to the original order, the experiment ended at an impasse. Viewers felt cheated expecting dramatic events similar to the Stanford Prison Experiment. The BBC aired hours of smoking and small talk with minimal action. From a TV perspective, the experiment exposed that without interference, ordinary people tend toward peace - maybe even forming a pacifist commune. Scientifically, it was a success with numerous publications, but its media impact didn't match the Stanford Prison Experiment. Zimbardo claims he’s no longer defending his project, viewing its longevity as validation despite criticisms over its manipulation.

parts.title: Rethinking the Bystander Effect
parts.body: In critical situations, bystanders can play a crucial role. Traditionally, the "bystander effect" suggested that the presence of others discourages individuals from helping. However, a meta-analysis of research studies shows that in life-threatening emergencies, the more bystanders present, the more likely people are to help. Researcher Marie Lindegaard argues that in most real-life situations, people help each other when they can communicate directly. This counters the negative narrative around Kitty Genovese's murder, where the responsibility for inaction was incorrectly placed on bystanders.

parts.title: The Psychology of Power
parts.body:
The Psychology of Power

Power behaves like a drug with many negative side effects. When people gain power, they often lose the kindness and modesty that initially helped them rise. Experiments showed that power can act like an anaesthetic, disconnecting individuals from others' emotions. Powerful people often become more impulsive, arrogant, and less empathetic. Studies reveal that feeling powerless makes individuals less confident and more hesitant to express their opinions. In modern democracies, shameless leaders can exploit this dynamic, as the media loves to spotlight the abnormal and absurd. Relying on charisma rather than integrity, they excel in our "mediacracies." Meanwhile, Homo puppy evolved shame as a form of self-regulation, vital within smaller, cooperative societies. Loss of shame in leadership can lead to corruption, and too much inequality can destabilize societies.

parts.title: Harnessing Reason for Collective Good
parts.body: Enlightenment Thinkers believed that while human nature may be selfish, they could channel self-interest through reason to benefit the common good. Greed was advocated as "private vices, public benefits" by thinkers like Adam Smith, emphasizing that selfish behaviors could lead to positive societal outcomes. Concepts like a free market were introduced, where individuals work together not from benevolence, but from personal interest. These ideas shaped notions of democracy and law, aiming to restrain selfish tendencies through systems like checks and balances in the US Constitution, ensuring power is held in check by other political entities. Justice and bureaucracy were framed to operate on reason, ensuring laws and procedures are unbiased, which moved societies away from religious judgement to trust in secular governance. The Age of Reason brought innovations like capitalism and the rule of law, which improved human safety, health, and economic conditions. However, critiques of this era, point out its dark side of racism and inequality, as thinkers, despite their views on selfishness, also saw humans as capable of empathy. David Hume highlighted a contradiction: political systems often assume selfish motives, while acknowledging humans are not purely self-interested. Ignoring inherent altruistic qualities may result in self-fulfilling prophecies of pessimism. Enlightenment mistakenly accepted a cynical view of human nature over inherent empathetic principles, prompting an inquiry if different societal systems acknowledging positive human attributes could be devised? These reflections nurture a part of the book focusing on rethinking institutions built on optimistic assumptions about human nature instead of cynicism.

parts.title: Simplicity and Trust in Systems
parts.body: Jos de Blok, known for embracing simplicity in healthcare, believes in creating systems that build on relationships and focus on care. He criticizes the healthcare system for becoming too bureaucratic, making healthcare more a business with sales teams and procurement units that lack healthcare expertise. De Blok suggests a straightforward approach, minimal billing complications, and emphasizes actual care over the administrative burden. Parallel to this, the text also touches on FAVI, a company that thrived under Jean-François Zobrist's leadership, who dismantled hierarchies and instilled trust and autonomy among employees, resulting in increased productivity and market share. Both FAVI and Buurtzorg exemplify the benefits of replacing suspicion with a positive, human-focused approach. The narrative argues for educational and systemic transformation where skill and competence prevail, envisioning a society driven by self-motivation.

parts.title: Everyday Communism and the Commons
parts.body: The chunk discusses the idea of communal sharing within a society, contrasting it with the negative perception of communism due to regimes like Russia under Lenin and Stalin. However, it highlights that everyday communism exists in families, workplaces, and interactions with strangers, such as asking for directions. The word 'communism' comes from the Latin 'communis,' which means communal, suggesting it is a foundation for societies. Historically, common resources (commons) were shared equally until states and multinationals appropriated them. The tragedy of the commons, a well-known theory by Garrett Hardin, describes how individuals exploiting a shared resource can lead to communal ruin, arguing for market or state control. Despite its impact, Elinor Ostrom, a political economist, countered Hardin by showing that people are capable of managing resources collaboratively, providing numerous examples worldwide and proving that commons can be successful with proper community management.

parts.title: Mandela's Journey & Contact Hypothesis
parts.body: The section explores the importance of contact and understanding between individuals from different backgrounds, highlighting Nelson Mandela's journey toward embracing nonviolent resistance. He learned Afrikaans, the language of his oppressors, to connect with them on a deeper level. This effort played a crucial role in winning the hearts of both black South Africans and, surprisingly, the white Afrikaners who once viewed him as a terrorist. Mandela's ability to build bridges across communities showcases the potential for transformation through empathy and communication, illustrating Gordon Allport’s contact hypothesis — that proximity and interaction reduce prejudice.

parts.title: Peppering Peace Through Christmas in Colombia
parts.body: In Colombia, 2006, ad men Carlos Rodriguez and Juan Pablo García from MullenLowe began using advertising tactics in the fight against the FARC guerrilla group. The Colombian defense minister recruited them to help weaken the guerrillas through guerrilla marketing. Instead of military attacks, they focused on understanding the human side of the fighters. Interviews with former FARC fighters revealed that these rebels were primarily ordinary people who desired connection and home—especially during times like Christmas. Recognizing Christmas as a time when demobilizations peaked, they set up Operation Christmas in December 2010, planting Christmas trees in the jungle with two thousand lights, urging guerrillas to return home. The lights activated with motion sensors attached to signs encouraging surrender. Within a month, 331 insurgents decided to lay down arms primarily because of the campaign, recognizing the familiar and comforting gesture over conventional war propaganda. This marketing made the insurgents feel more humanized than monstrously cast as merely rebels.

parts.title: The Real Lord of the Flies
parts.body:
Title: The Real Lord of the Flies

In the book's introduction, William Golding reflects on his notorious novel, "Lord of the Flies." Golding's work, based on his belief that man is inherently selfish, enthralls academics. However, there’s a true story that challenges this dark view. In 1965, a group of boys in Tonga survived on an island for 15 months without descending into chaos or violence, contrary to Golding’s narrative. Unlike Golding’s boys, they organized kitchens, maintained a fire, and created a communal society—highlighting a nuanced picture of human nature. Researchers Frans de Waal and Steve Bowman describe accounts that human behavior in captivity or extreme isolation doesn’t always lead to savagery. Goldman and others critique societal norms and hegemonic thoughts on human nature and survival tactics. Contemporary scholars contemplate how people, even in challenging contexts like reality shows and fraternities, often defy expectations — undermining the "inherently violent" man myth.

parts.title: The Paradox of Empathy and Morality
parts.body: The importance of empathy is discussed in relation to moral judgment and justice. Daniel Batson argues that empathy can cause conflict between compassion and justice, as empathizing with someone might lead one to be less punitive than warranted. Paul Bloom adds that empathy can have a paradoxical effect, sometimes reducing punishment where it is due (Bloom, *Against Empathy*). The "moralisation gap" concept is introduced, suggesting our tendency to see harm done to us as worse than harm we inflict on others, driving cycles of conflict and retribution.

parts.title: About Rutger Bregman and Publication Details
parts.body: Rutger Bregman is a well-regarded historian known for his popular book "Utopia for Realists", which has been translated into multiple languages and became a bestseller. He writes for notable publications like the Washington Post and the Guardian, and his TED talk on poverty has millions of views. Recognized as a leading changemaker, Bregman's influence stretches across Europe and beyond, primarily through his work at The Correspondent. The book is published by Bloomsbury Publishing, a renowned publishing company known for its widespread distribution and high-profile authors. Originally written in Dutch and released in the Netherlands, this work has been made available in Great Britain since 2020. Bregman retains the copyrights to his book under the Copyright, Designs and Patents Act, 1988, safeguarding his work against unauthorized reproduction.
